item.title: Trump Says He Will Release Files on Aliens and U.F.O.s
item.description: President Trump had lashed out at former President Barack Obama earlier Thursday for telling a podcaster that aliens were real.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said that he has directed his administration to begin releasing files related to aliens.

item.title: New Trump Banner Hung on Justice Dept. Headquarters in D.C.
item.description: Other federal buildings across Washington, D.C., are also adorned with huge banners of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Justice in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Has a Head-Spinning Day, but Republicans Want Him to Focus
item.description: President Trump’s advisers want him to lock down a message on the economy that will resonate ahead of the midterms. But Mr. Trump is never one to stay on message.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump used much of his speech in Rome, Ga., on Thursday to address tangents: railing against the Supreme Court, making false claims of voter fraud and calling himself a “schmuck” for donating his presidential salary.

item.title: HUD Revives First-Term Trump Proposal to Eject Undocumented Immigrants from Public Housing
item.description: When the Trump administration proposed the rule in 2019, housing officials estimated it would also displace thousands of U.S. citizens and legal residents.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A public housing complex in New York City.

item.title: Bard College Opens Review of Its President’s Ties to Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: The move comes after a trove of documents released by the Justice Department showed Leon Botstein had a relationship that was closer than previously known with the convicted sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bard College campus in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.

item.title: MAHA Moms Turn Against Trump: ‘Women Feel Like They Were Lied To’
item.description: President Trump’s executive order aimed at spurring production of a pesticide has infuriated leaders of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s MAHA movement.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. onstage with him at a news conference last year.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Iran Strikes, He Declines to Make Clear Case for Why
item.description: Rarely in modern times has the United States prepared to conduct a major act of war with so little explanation or public debate.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the inaugural Board of Peace meeting in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Calls Himself a ‘Schmuck’ for Donating His Presidential Salary
item.description: President Trump complained that he gets “no credit” for the donations, though his family has done more to monetize the presidency than anyone who has ever occupied the White House.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump spoke at the Coosa Steel Corporation in Rome, Ga., on Thursday.

item.title: Police Investigate ICE Arrest of a Man Who Suffered Severe Head Injuries
item.description: The police in St. Paul, Minn., are investigating an arrest last month during the immigration crackdown. The man has said he was beaten by agents. ICE asserted that he ran into a wall.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Mark Vancleave/Associated Press
item.media:description: Alberto Castañeda Mondragón told The Associated Press that he was in a friend’s car at a shopping center in St. Paul, Minn., when immigration agents pulled him from the car.

item.title: Trump’s Board of Peace Promises Billions for Gaza, With Few Details
item.description: At the inaugural meeting of his new organization, President Trump also endorsed a divisive foreign leader and heard an attack on his former prosecutor, Jack Smith.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nine Board of Peace member countries have agreed to contribute more than $7 billion to the Gaza rebuilding effort, President Trump announced Thursday.

item.title: With ‘Tremendous’ Deals at Stake, Trump Is Bringing Russia in From the Cold
item.description: Since President Trump took office more than a year ago, the Kremlin has dangled possible investments in front of the famously transactional leader. The message is starting to resonate with investors.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a meeting in Alaska last year.

item.title: Powerful Winds and Wildfires Have the Southern Plains on Edge
item.description: A combustible mix of weather ingredients has sparked worries about new fires in Oklahoma and Texas.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Amy Graff
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Gov. Abigail Spanberger Will Deliver Democratic Response to Trump’s State of the Union
item.description: In selecting the Virginia governor, Democrats turned to a centrist former congresswoman whose winning campaign last year showed how their party’s candidates can succeed in the Trump era.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Abigail Spanberger of Virginia in early February. A Democrat, she was elected in the purple state by 15 points, a victory that buoyed her party.

item.title: Judge Orders Hearings for Immigration Detainees and Condemns ‘Terror Against Noncitizens’
item.description: As tensions mount between the Trump administration and the courts, the judge called “shameless” a claim by officials that her earlier order was not binding.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents arresting an unidentified man in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: With a Golden Gavel and a Threat to Iran, Trump Launches His Board of Peace
item.description: The first gathering of President Trump’s alternative to the United Nations is a manifestation of a Trump World Order.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Refugees Without Green Cards Could Be Arrested Under New Trump Policy
item.description: The change is part of the administration’s broad effort to target refugees and tighten pathways for immigrants to legally enter or remain in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Immigration agents stopping drivers in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Epstein Built Ties to U.S. Customs Officers, Prompting Criminal Investigation
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein cultivated friendly relationships with several customs officers in the U.S. Virgin Islands, offering food, advice and even musical gigs.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich and Steve Eder
item.media:credit: Gabriella N. Baez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little St. James, a private island owned by Jeffrey Epstein in the Caribbean.

item.title: Two Sisters Died in Tahoe Area Avalanche During Trek With Friends
item.description: Families and friends of the women, many from the Bay Area, confirmed their identities. The women went on regular trips to the Tahoe region and were experienced skiers, the families said.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Heather Knight and Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trail to Castle Peak in the Lake Tahoe region on Wednesday.

item.title: Doing Your Taxes? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: The New York Times is looking to speak to Americans about how the most recent tax cuts are affecting their pocketbooks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press

item.title: A Press Freedom Case in Peril, From a Lawyer Who Helped Write It
item.description: Alan Dershowitz was present at the creation of New York Times v. Sullivan. Now he is asking the Supreme Court to revise or destroy it.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: New York Times v Sullivan (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Alan Dershowitz during the impeachment trial of President Trump in January 2020.

item.title: In Lake Tahoe Avalanche Recovery, the Safety of Searchers Is Top Concern
item.description: Weather and snow conditions will dictate when the bodies of skiers killed in the avalanche near Lake Tahoe can be retrieved from mountain. More snow is expected.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Digging out a friend’s truck at the Castle Peak trailhead. Eight backcountry skiers have been confirmed dead in an avalanche in the Castle Peak area at Donner Pass on Wednesday.

item.title: Arts Panel Packed With Trump Allies Approves White House Ballroom Project
item.description: President Trump has eliminated any pocket of resistance from within his administration to his plans for a 90,000-square-foot ballroom.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of the demolished East Wing of the White House last month. President Trump has taken several steps to eliminate resistance to his ballroom plans.

item.title: Why Is Trump Dumping East Wing Rubble in a Public Park?
item.description: The East Potomac Golf Links is a municipal course that has been a fixture in Washington for decades. President Trump is turning it into something else.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh and Kent Nishimura
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

item.title: Leon Botstein, Bard College’s President, Had Epstein Ties. He Is Also Seen as a Campus Savior.
item.description: The president of Bard College raised millions to save his school from closure. As he sought donations, he talked with Jeffrey Epstein about music, watches and young female musicians.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Botstein has been leading Bard College since 1975.

item.title: Ohio’s Covid Czar Hopes to Be the State’s Democratic Governor
item.description: Amy Acton’s service to retiring Gov. Mike DeWine gives her bipartisan credibility in a Republican state, but that service, leading Ohio’s pandemic response, also stirs charged emotions.
item.dc:creator: Kate Zernike
item.media:credit: Jessica Phelps for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy Acton is looking to become the second elected Democratic governor in the state in the last 35 years.

item.title: After Avalanche Warnings, a Sierra Nevada Tragedy
item.description: Eight skiers were killed and one other was presumed dead in the deadliest snow disaster in modern California history. Six were found alive.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: An avalanche beacon checkpoint flashes along a trail to Castle Peak near Donner Pass on Wednesday.
